bestBHT.bht: No one at the table, not even St. John who knew he was the traitor, had any idea that the act of betrayal was going to happen so soon. This is significant because it reveals how carefully Jesus had kept the secret and exposed Judas's hypocrisy until the last moment. It is a reminder that even those who knew Judas's true nature did not fully comprehend the extent of his intentions.

Henry Alford: Not even St. John: who knew he was the traitor, but had no idea the deed was so soon to be done.
Stier supposes St. John to exclude himself in saying 'no man at the table,' and that he knew.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: But what we need ... or, ... give ... to the poor—a very important statement, as showing how carefully Jesus had kept the secret, and Judas his hypocrisy, to the last.
But what we need ... or, ... give ... to the poor—a very important statement, as showing how carefully Jesus had kept the secret, and Judas his hypocrisy, to the last.
But what we need ... or, ... give ... to the poor—a very important statement, as showing how carefully Jesus had kept the secret, and Judas his hypocrisy, to the last.
John Calvin: Either John had not yet related to others what Christ had told him, or they were so much struck by it, that they lost their presence of mind."
And, indeed, ill is probable, that John himself was almost out of his senses."
But what then happened to the disciples, we frequently see: taking place in the Church, that few of the believers discern the hypocrites whom the Lord loudly condemns.
Philip Schaff: No one of those reclining at meat perceived for what intent he said it unto him.
Even although they now knew that he was to betray his Master, they might be so ignorant of all the steps he was to take for that end.
They could not attach a correct idea to the words addressed to him.
Archibald T. Robertson: No one knew (ουδεις εγνω). Second aorist active indicative of γινωσκω. The disciples had not yet perceived the treacherous heart of Judas.
John Gill: Now no man at the table... knew for what intent he spake this unto him."
...he might not know the meaning of his last words, that he spoke concerning the act of betraying him.
...did not imagine that the thing was so near and so speedily to be done, as it was.
John Wesley: None knew why he said this — Save John and Judas.

bhtAttempts.bht: No one at the table, not even St. John who knew he was the traitor, had any idea that the act of betrayal was going to happen so soon. This is significant because it reveals how carefully Jesus had kept the secret and exposed Judas's hypocrisy until the last moment. It is a reminder that even those who knew Judas's true nature did not fully comprehend the extent of his intentions. Such ignorance and lack of understanding can still occur in the Church today, where believers may struggle to discern the hypocrisy of those condemned by the Lord.

No one at the table, not even St. John who knew he was the traitor, had any idea that the act of betrayal was imminent. This highlights the careful secrecy kept by Jesus and exposes Judas's hypocrisy until the very end. It serves as a reminder that even those aware of someone's true nature may not fully grasp the extent of their intentions. This lack of understanding can still be observed in the Church today, where believers may struggle to discern the hypocrisy that the Lord condemns.
